, Convocation aftermath

Can Johns Hopkins University live with Princess Ashraf?

Baltimore Police outside Lyric
•

By ERIC GARLAND
The awarding of an honorary degree to
Princess Ashraf Pahlavi of Iran at last
Sunday's convocation ceremonies has
aroused considerable controversy about
the University's intentions and integrity.
Hopkins has seemingly ignored the
Princess' background, the political
activities of the Shah,(her twin brother),
and protests from the community.
The University's official connection
With Iran is an academic exchange
Program between theSchool of Health
Services and the College of Health
Sciences at the Reza Pahlavi Medical
Center in Tehran. The Iranian Students
Association (ISA) holds that the Shah has
donated money to the Med School, and
that the degree was granted in response to
(and in hopes of future) grants. Dr. Harry
Woolf, Provost of the University, has said,
"We don't get any money from the
Iranian government, only the fees
covering faculty expenses at the College."
The jump from the exchange program
relationship to the degree award to
Ashraf reveals a very murky process.
Woolf heads the Honorary Degree
Committee, which is composed of seven
members from all divisions of the
University. Dr. Richard Macksey stressed
that the Committee is more concerned
With the Commencement awards in May,
While the President customarily
nominates . the Commemoration
speaker(s). The Committee last met
October 28 to review a memo sent by
Woolf listing the candidates for February
and May. "We're not concerned on a
discussion basis with Commemoration
Day," said Macksey, "if the Committee
exists, the Committee ratifies." The three
recipients of Commemoration degrees
were proposed by President Muller; they
were perfunctorily . approved by the
committee, with no questions asked or
Protests received. No vitae, however, was
supplied about the candidates."We know
there's controversy," said Woolf, "but
don't know the facts of the charges. It
looked pretty clean to me at the time."
Mike Hoffheimer, a Hopkins junior and
one of five persons arrested Sunday,
replied that "if he feels that way, it's
embarassing for an institution to not
know what's going on in the world. How
could it look clean, with people from
Hopkins over there, seeing what's going
on."
Woolf termed Ashraf s nomination
symbolic", citing her role in helping and
guiding the development of the College of
Health Sciences. In the terms of an ISA
member, the Princess, "after the Shah, is
the most hated person by all people in

Iran." Ashraf s reputation is notorious, to
say. the least. "Of all women in the
world," stated ne faculty member,"why
was she singled out, a woman with that
kind of reputation, from that kind of
government?"
The Washington Post, February 23,
1976, reported that "one of the Shah's
closest relatives who continues to be
surrounded by widespread suspicion is his
twin sister, Princess Ashraf, a world
leader in woman's rights movements. The
Princess, whose three marriages and
jet-set living style have offended many
Iranians, is said to be deeply involved in a
number of 'shady deals'. 'Take the
trucking industry: said a wealthy Tehran
businessman, 'not a truck can move
anywhere without a payoff going to
Ashraf.' In the days before Iran was
swimming in oil wealth, it was widely
believed that Princess Ashraf profited
from illegal opium deals involving Iran's
large poppy production."
This latter charge is documented by
Michael Parrish, an Indiana University
faculty member, in the December 1962
issue of The Minority of One."Two years
ago," he writes, "the Swiss police arrested
the Shah's sister, Princess Ashraf, for
having several suitcases full of heroin."
She was on her way to the U.S. at the
time. Hoffheimer added that "she has
been arrested for drug-running at least
three times in European airports," and
that her diplomatic immunity had been
used to successfully carry out the
operations. Her personal trafficking may
have been discontinued with the wealth
brought by Iranian oil (thus freeing her to
be a "humanitarian"), but Iran remains
the country with the most addicts per
population (an estimated half million by
the New York Times), and the Shah in
1969 removed a ban which prohibited the
cultivation of opium.
The political corruption of the royal
family was described by Nation, April 12,
1965. It seems that the donation of
millions of U.S. foreign aid dollars to Iran
was quickly followed by the deposit of
millions in a numbered Swiss bank
account to the "Pahlavi Foundation".
Photostat copies of the account revealed
a $3 million check withdrawn to Ashraf,
an amount exceeded only by $15 million
given to the Shah's wife. Eleven years
later the Post is still reporting on the
"suspected" corruption of the Shah and
his relatives.
The Post, though, falters in describing
Ashraf "a world leader in woman's rights

movements." "Perhaps she is representing
the rights of the woman of her type or
class," said the ISA member. "The
women of Iran, the workers and patriots,
are worse off than ever. The workers
make fifty cents a day; women prisoners
are tortured and raped in front of their
husbands and brothers."
The political repression of the Shah's
regime is unquestioned. Martin Ennals,
Secretary of Amnesty International, has
stated that "no country in the world has
a worse record in human rights than
Iran." There are an estimated 100,000
political prisoners (4000 women), the
majority of whom are tortured; at least
four hundred have been executed in the
past four years. Secret military tribunals
decide the fate of prisoners, with
torture-induced confessions common.
Repeated attempts by international
organizations to send observ,l
have been
met with forced deportations.
"No one can claim to be naive about
that (the political repression)," said the
professor. Woolf, though, declared that
"it's not our role to judge" and said the
controversy was dismissed at the time of
selection. "We try to have candidates
with a bearing on the University, some
kind of proper affiliation," he explained.
"The Princess was awarded as a patron of
the University program in Iran." Again,
the faculty member questioned, "why
her, why not a doctor, or someone in the

The Princess Ashraf

health program?" Ashrafs position with
the College of Health Sciences, as the
"political and monetary backbone"(from
a Hopkins doctor involved in the
program), is not the result of any special
merit; she was appointed by the Shah.,
"When Hopkins does something like
that," the ISA member said, "it
legitimates Iran and its reactionary
regime."
The process of the degree award was
not handled like a ceremonious event.
The Honorary Degree Committee,
naturally, knew of the nomination, but
both Macksey and Dr. Owen Phillips had
trouble recalling the minimal approval
procedure, and 'Macksey only
remembered Ashraf when reading over
the convocation procedure Sunday
morning. Outside of the marshals, no
faculty members were told of the
conferral; "nobody had the chance to
protest," said the professor. When one of
the persons invited to be a marshal
withdrew upon seeing the selection of the
Princess, the University quietly ignored
his action. Most people first found out
about Ashraf's award at the
Commemoration Sunday.
One group that knew well in advance,
however, was SAVAK, Iranian secret
police. In cooperation with Hopkins
security, federal agents (one in a Hopkins
security uniform), and the Baltimore City
Police, agents in plain clothes were at the
Lyric Theater under the cover of
"newspaper reporters". When the
demonstration inside the theater began,
the SAVAK agents physically carried
people out of the auditorium,
undertaking all the police duties up to the
actual arrest. SAVAK had meetings and
radio contact with the police; in short,
they were condoned by the University.
Bodyguards for foreign visitors is normal
procedure, but in this case, the emphasis
was on hiding any connection with the
Iranian government.
As for the arrest, Hoffheimer and the
four others had to wait six hours in jail
before they were told of the charges
against them (disorderly conduct). While
they were in the basement of the Lyric,
the police were heard negotiating who
was to be the arresting officer.
Hoffheimer asked who the officer was;
the reply, "I'll tell you later." During the
booking, the police were on radio talking
to Hopkins security about the charges.
Apparently, the six hour delay was due to
the time taken by the administration to
decide on the charges. Another gloss on
the arrest is the fact that Hopkins
security guards were brought into the jail
to identify the protesters for sure
identification at the trial later.
With the award of the degree to Ashraf
and the arrest of the demonstrators past
history, the University now has to justify
its actions. The protesters did upset the
ceremony, with Woolf remarking that
"it's not a road to justice," and that it
was "a disruption of Hopkins' private
celebration." Hoffheimer counters, of
course, that "Ashraf is breaking into
Iranian lives every day. An honorary
degree is not a private thing; Ashraf is not
just an ordinary person." The
presentation of the doctorate, with the
"short-circuit" of the Degree Committee,
the secrecy surrounding information
about the award, and the Princess' and
Iran's backgrounds, calls for something
beyond the citation words of last Sunday.

We urge you to watch closely

It would abridge freedom of

It would excuse governmental

of the principals in Watergate.
It would sanction and

It would vastly increase
penalties for victimless crimes

pornography.
It would seriously weaken
constitutional guarantees
established in the Supreme
Court's Miranda decision,
encourage police entrapment and
make insanity as a defense nearly
imp ossible.
The list could go on and on.
The bill is an obscenity. Those
disenchanted with the .policies
and practices of the United
States over the last several
decades still enjoy a remarkable
degree of liberty. SB-1 is an
assualt on this liberty. It is
frightening that SB-1 should be
the object of serious
consideration. But such are the
times that it could achieve not
just consideration, but passage.

Towson State radio goes FM
By J.D. CONSIDINE
About a year ago, I happened
to be in the Towson State
College Student Center, and in
the course of my wanderings, I
noticed music pervading the
general hotel-lobby atmosphere
of the building. Muzak, I figured
(although it was far more hip
than the general WLIF fare);
until a voice was discerned
mumbling some explanation of
what was played.
This was WVTS, Towson's
carrier current station. Like most
carrier current stations, it had a
limited following, intermittant
broadcast hours, and very little
potential. Unbeknownst to the
general public, though, help was
on the way: FM.
Right now, Towson is in its
third week of FM programming,
with WCVT-FM a broadcast
reality at 89. What may seem to
be an overnight transition,
however, was anything but
sudden; the metamorphosis of
Carrier Current to FM took over
three years.
What does it take to go FM?
"A lot of work," to quote station
manager Steve Curran. Outside of
the basic procedure of obtaining
permission, a frequency, and a
license there are the problems
involved in equipment.
First of all, money. The cost
for Towson's FM station has
been almost entirely for
equipment, and has totalled
approximately $36,000. With the
exception of the tower
construction ( due to county
laws), all equipment installation
has been done by _student
volunteers.
But there were also problems
with personnel, and fulfilling the
F.C.C. guidelines for an
Educational FM station.
For starters, the station is
almost entirely student staffed
and managed. This creates a
strong core of support for the
station, but it also has
drawbacks. When exams and
vacations occur, it will not be
easy to get all the DJ's to their
shows, let alone on time.
"Mid-terms are coming up," says
Curran, "and this should be an
indication of how things will go."
Although he expects to weather
the exams, the end of the term
poses yet another problem. Even
with 90% of the staff living in the
area as full-time residents, Curran
expects scheduling problems.
As an educational station, they
are obligated to serve the
community, which right now is
not easy. "Since we went on in
Mid-term, we really couldn't start
any educational courses-by-radio,
"Curran stated.
For now, they have two
student created and produced
educational programs, Media
Makers and Business Beat,
broadcast from 9:00-9:30
weekdays. The rest of the
programming is based on
Classical music from 6:00-9:00
a.m., and Jazz from 8:00 to
midnight. The rest of the
broadcast day is 'progressive
radio'."
Doesn't all that progressive
sound like typical carrier-current
radio? "Yeah, and I'm not too

pleased, but at the moment,
there's not a whole lot I can do,"
said Curran. "We're a new
station, and we've still got a lot
of growing to do."
When asked about the chances
for an FM station at Hopkins,
Curran gave this evaluation:
"I really can't see Hopkins
with an FM station for at least
five years. There's a lot of
preliminary action that has to be
taken, and one thing that is
essential is an experienced
Advisor, with radio background
and an F.C.C. first class license.

It just makes everything so much
easier; he would know how to fill
out the forms, how to deal with
the government officials.
"As for a Mass Comm
program, you don't need to be a
Mass Comm major to be in radio.
You could just as easily be an Art
Student.
"It's fastest if you can get all
volunteers. Of course it will take
time; you've got to expect it to
change hands. But we had full
support of our Student
Government, and it's taken a
long time, but we're here."

The return of the
Thin White Duke
Station to Station, David
Bowie's latest lp, is already
beginning to generate a
snowballing excitement with
multiple hits flying out of radios
into the waiting ears of his
beloved young Americans. The
"Thin White Duke" is staging
more than a return; the boy with
the animal grace has carefully
mapped out a Bowie year; after
the whirlwind coast-to-coast
tour, a movie will be released for
all of us to gawk and coo at, and
from there Bowie's momentum
and ability to mesmerize his
audience could carry him
anywhere—perhaps to his own
recently disclosed fancy of ruling
the world.
Though Bowie has more fans
than ever, long-standing
aficionados of the man can only
feel some disappointment at the
general musical mediocrity of
Station to Station. It is a
reflection of Bowie's lastest
remarks in Rolling Stone
magazine where he denounced
rock 'n roll. as "musical soma,"
very close to "becoming an
immobile, sterile fascist that
constantly spews its propaganda
on every arm of the media." But
the writing on the new album
remains intensely personal, joyful
and optimistic, having its roots in
Thinky Dory and earlier works.
The new devotees applaud the
absense of glitter and feminine

garb, but it should be
remembered that the
androgynous darling has always
remained a few steps ahead of
the pack and now points to a
mellowing in these golden years.
There can be no doubt that
David Bowie is about to make his
bid for messiah, a role he's
groomed himself for these last
seven years. What is scary is that
Bowie's remarks on the potential
dangers of popular music seem to
be exactly what he is
trying—except that I think he has
some important things to say.
always has. He is about to launch
a cinema career and start his own
production • company. To be sure.
the future theatrics of David
Bowie will be more interesting
than national political struggles
to the average American. Let's
hope -somebody , maybe even
Bowie himself, has enough
common sense to keep things uI
perspective.
But remember, we are dealing
with the one and only ZiggY
Stardust. Bowie has put down his
past roles, but Ziggy was an
amazing piece of autobiography,
and has so far proven to be the
true David Bowie story.'
We are about to witness not
only Bowie's rock 'n roll suicide,
but most likely ours as well.
David Bowie will be appearing
at the Capitol Center on March
13 and 14.

To the Editor:
I was pleased at your less than
customary fullness of coverage of
the various Centennial Weekend
• symposia. Though overdue, your
implicit recognition of the
immense value of these
presentations and exchanges to
the primary academic purposes
of a university is welcome.
My applause is not, however,
without reservations. First, you
might have criticized the
overabundance of these
symposia. No mind, trapped
within a single body, could have
been exposed to even a majority
of the participants' .comments.
Second—and this is quite serious
in a journal with any pretension

he symposium on "The

was left unsigned. This is
inexcusable, however just the
opinions of the reviewer.

To the Editor:
Hopkins cannot expect to
endure another 100 years as a
private educational institution
unless the university respects the
right of individuals to speak
freely. By pressing charges
against the persons who
demonstrated at the centennial
celebration, JHU is compounding
its disgrace. Without further
moralizing, I urge the University
to drop these outrageous charges.
Marie Nally

women led
her to mobilize the educated and
affluent women of her country.
The organization which resulted
from this activity has evolved
into a model center for service to
women. Pricess Ashraf holds as a
basic truth the proposition that
only when women achieve their
full potential in human society
will men achieve theirs.
When Her Imperial Highness
was appointed to the United
Nations as chief of the Iranian
delegation, she exploited this
international forum to continue
her dedication to humanitarian
cuases. In 1968, she became the
first woman to preside over a
major international
proceeding—the International
Conference on Human Rights. In
1975, she was instrumental in the
organization of the International
Women's Year Program and was a
major author of the World Plan
of Action approved in Mexico
City by delegates from 130
nations calling for the
achievement of full and equal
rights for women throughout the
world in the course of the next

decade.
The Johns Hopkins University
has a special interest in the honor
we bestow today upon Princess
Ashraf. Medical care, particularly
for those outside major
population centers, is one of her
country's most critical problems.
Over the years, many Iranian
physicians have received their
training at Johns Hopkins, and
because of that earlier experience
an academic exchange program
has been established between this
University and the College of
Health Sciences at the Reza
Pahlavi Medical Center in Tehran.
The goal is to develop a broad
spectrum of health professionals
to meet the specific needs of
Iran, where over half the
population still resides in small
villages.

This program has by no means
been an unidirectional learning
experience. Physicians in this
country, too, are clustered
around population centers, and
the solutions found in Iran to the
problem of maldistiibution
medical care may have a
significant impact upon the
delivery of medical care in the
United States. The success of this
entire effort is no small measure
of a reflection of the foresight of
Princess Ashraf, who earlY
recognized the needs of her
people and helped bring together
her country's resources to meet
those needs.
Mr. President, it is a distinct
pleasure to present for the degree
of Doctor of Laws, Her Imperial
Highness, Princess Ashraf Pahlavi
of Iran.

It'd be safe to say that the
person who hacked out the above
blurb should be hawking fortunes
instead of wasting away at the
publicity desk of the Office of
Special Events.
Most of us were tricked. I
mean,to the men and women in
Shriver and Garland Halls, all
University ceremonies are major,
and so the publicist inevitably
trumps the affair up for more
than it actually is. Usually,
Commemoration Day
celebrations are dull to begin
with, and as they proceed,
become duller yet. It's true that
the procession is quite a
spectacle, and even inspiring for a
few crazy moments, but its
novelty is gone once the speeches
begin. Therefore, when we read
that this event was major, well,
that didn't say a hell of a lot.
But wehad no idea. Who knew
that Hopkins was tossing an
honorary degree to a woman who
is not only tied to the tyrannical
Iranian government, but alleged
to have overseen vast drug
smuggling units as well? Who
would have guessed that the
Centennial Convocation would
be the leading story on the
Sunday night late news? And
who could have predicted that
Steven Muller would emerge
from the Centennial finale with a
stain on his administration
instead of the crown everyone
had expected.
As friends of the Universio
arrived at the Lyric Theatre,
scattered groups were
distributing leaflets outside, but
in numbers no greater than those
usually brought out by a
gathering of this size. An obvious
thought was that maybe the
Labor Party would continue their
harassment of Muller inside, but
then, Shriver Hall, scene of past
interruptions, was not quite the
Lyric.

smoothly. The Baltimore
Symphony set a dignified tone,
John Barth played announcer
when the procession started, and
all the Hopkins heavyweights
found their places on stage. Had
nothing else happened that day,
the chief irony would have been
the presence of Lincoln Gordon,
who was seated next to Muller
while Robert D. H. Harvey
praised the current president for
his restoration of Hopkin's
finances. As it turns out, that
little twist will rate as mere trivia
when this Commemoration Day
is remembered.

Delta Phi tops brands X, IT and Z easily
By MIKE DEAK
Fraternity Party!
The phrase alone harkens
visions of old movies and foolish
dreams, of more prosaic times
when the threat of communism
was not yet upon the land. Ali
yes, I can see it now. The
Whiffenpoof Club harmonizing
"The Sweetheart of Sigma Chi"
while crooning young men
rowing on the lake strum their
ukeleles and serenade their
amantes. Meanwhile, back at
the fraternity house, couples
have strewn themselves about the
veranda engaging in some heavy
necking, never daring-- God
forbid!--to go all the way. And if,
at the end of the evening while a
Connie Francis record coos softly
in the background, some
romantic fraternity brother pins
his girl, she has all the right in the
world to consider herself a
"lucky lady".
Needless to say, this just is not
the case anymore. Like all other
great American institutions,
fraternities have taken a severe
beating in the last decade.
Radical ideas undermined the
basic bourgeois concept of
fraternities, changing them into
nothing more than formalized
social clubs. In the late sixties,
hippies rightly charged
fraternities as being not relevant
enough, paragons of what was
wrong in America. So, like
fugitive radicals, fraternities went
underground waiting for more
politically petceful times to
make a rousing comeback. Now,
with the apathetic seventies upon
us like a shroud, frats have risen
from the grave and once again
gained a status that has to be
reckoned with.
I don't know what made me
attend the numberous fraternity
parties this month. Perhaps it was
the anthropology major showing

through, the relentless
ethnographer gathering data for
that ultimate monograph on
American puberty rites. Or, more
likely, the current sultry
February weather brings out a
reckless streak of hedonism in
me, just as heat applied to a boil
will bring the pus to the surface.
Whatever ther eason, I put on my
most elegant finery and bravely
ventured onto the dark Baltimore
streets in search of cheap thrills
and fraternity parties.
I should have gone no further
than my first stop, St. Elmo's
Hall, the grand residence of Delta
Phi. In past years, Delta Phi had
achieved a nefarious and false
reputation of being nothing more
than a den of stuffed shirts and
spoiled preppies. But the only
truth in these allegations is in the
fraternity's boast of having "the
highest class drunks around." In
reality, Delta Phi members are no
different than the rest of us
except they are a tad more
affluent and conservative. These
last two traits should not be
frowned upon because they
enable the fraternity to give the
best parties at Hopkins.

With their virtually unlimited
resources, Delta Phi was able to
snare Rodeo Rick for its parties.
Most importantly, for hard
drinkers like myself, Delta Phi
had the sense and class to have
imported Dortmunder Union
beer and to serve it in authentic
glasses. The dark draught flowed
easily over the palate and gave
the tastebuds a thrill they will
not soon forget. With cries of
"Beer here" in the finest Yankee
Stadium tradition emanating
from behind the bar, I forgot I
was at a fraternity party and
started enjoying myself.
Using the flimsy excuse that I
had to pay my respects to other
friends, I had to take leave of
Delta Phi and stumble to the
next fraternity. Unfortunately,
fraternity X (I use the
anonymous letter due to the
stringent laws of libel) proved to
be a foreshadowing of the
mediocore parties to follow.
Walking into X (after talking to
an Arab friend outside; X attracts
all kinds) was like entering a
funeral parlor whose air
conditioning had broken down.
The narrow entrance hall was

lined with lacrosse sticks am
bodies. You could tell th.
difference; the sticks were no
drinking beer.
Making my way through thi:
serious parody of a somnabulis
convention, I was reminded o
Orpheus' descent into Hades. TM
rooms were so dimly lit I coulc
hardly see whose feet I wa
trampling. Once I reached th.
bar I was sorry I had. The bee I
tasted as though it was brewed it •
a bathtub on the third floor so :
carefully poured my cupful ont(
the nearest potted plant. Makin!
a quick exit, I swear I saw a gir
sucking her thumb but thes(
things can never be verified.
Fraternity Y is just up th(
road and around the corner fronX. Y has a reputation for havini
the liveliest parties in town but ir
several trips, I have found the
merriment never to rise above z
tepid level. The popularity of V
is beyond my comprehension. I
could never forge my way
through the throng surrounding
the bar so I was unable to taste
their beer. The band sounded as
if their last gig was at the Kit Kat
Klub on Pulaski Highway. On the
spacious dance floor, several girls
hustled with each other. Not
lc-lowing what to make of this, I
quickly escaped this hotbed of
sin and fled to Z. just a stroll in
the jungle from Y.
Z had less walking zombies
than either X or Y. By this time,
I was lurching to one side and
bleating intermittant belches.
Not caring about the
consequences, I began a game of
subtle charades, an amateurish
form of "Stump the Stars", with
a young lady trying to ferret out
any kind of reciprocal affection.
Alas, I proved to be an
incompetent mime and was left
at the end of the evening with
nobody to pin.

STUDY IN THE HIMALAYAS THIS SUMMER
A seven-week expedition is planned for this summer to study the human ecology of the Himalayas.
There is a planned program of study including the area of health and nutrition. Trekking from an
elevation of 1,500 feet down in the jungles of Nepal, up through the heart of the Himalayas to an
elevation of 15,000 feet, high on the arid Tibetan Plateau behind the major mountain massifs of
Dhaulagiri and Annapurna, the class will study the way different people live and why. The
comprehensive fee that covers all expenses if $1,935 from May 25th to July 11th. Three semester
hours of credit possible through the Department of Geography and Enviromental Engineering at
Johns Hopkins. Credits require approval by the Department and by the Dean of Undergraduate
Studies after completion of the program of study and submission of a satisfactory paper. For
information, contact: The Woodlands Institute, Spruce Knob Mountain, Cherry Grove, West Virginia
26803 or M.G. Wolman, Ames 513, JHU.

1976 Hopkins lacrosse: looking for finer fortunes
By STEPHEN LEVIN
WE HAVE A COUPLE OF
SCORES TO SETTLE!
That's the call to arms as the
1976 Hopkins lacrosse team
convenes for its opening week of
Practice. With memories of a
bitterly disappointing ending to
what had opened as an extremely
Promising season fresh .in their
minds, Coach Henry Ciccarone,
his staff and players are out to
avenge the two late season losses
which destroyed all hopes for an
undefeated year and with that
the chance for an unprecedented

second straight NCAA title.
The Blue Jays finished a highly
respectable third in the final
season poll especially considering
the season had been termed a
"rebuilding" one at the outset
due to the loss of eleven seniors
from 1974's national
championship squad.
In recapping the 1975 season,
one has to start with the
elevation of Henry Ciccarone
from the position of associate
coach to the head coaching spot
when Robert Scott left ro
dedicate all of his time to his

duties as Athletic
Director. Chic got a rude
introduction to his head coaching
duties when Hopkins opened its'
title defense by edging a spirited
bunch of Wahoos from Virginia
10-9 in overtime on Homewood
Field.
Impressive victories followed
over weaker opponents Denison,
Yale, Washington College and
Princeton. Against the Tigers,
Hopkins unleashed its most
furious offensive barrage of the
season, papering the Princeton
net with 22 goals!

All this resulted in a number
one ranking for the Homewood
stickmen and set-up the first of
two consecutive clashes which
would truly test the Jays'
strength. First was the clash between
the collegiate champs and the
club champs; Hopkins vs. the
Long Island Lacrosse Club, a
Saturday night game at
Homewood. What was previewed
as a titanic struggle between the
best of two worlds turned into a
rout with the uppity youngsters
dominating, 20-9.

By BRUCE FOX
Hopkins' Comforteers will
play host to the Middle Atlantic
Conference Swimming and
Diving Championships this
weekend, after closing out their
regular season schedule with a
54-50 win over Dickinson College
Tuesday.
The Dickinson meet, held at
Carlisel, Penn., was one of the
easiest of the season for the Blue
Jays, with many of Hopkins'
swimmers either not swimming
or entering events other than
their specialties.

Freshman Roy Beveridge was a
dual winner in the mmet,
combining a Dickinson pool
record-setting performance in the
200-yard freestyle (1:53.9) with
a first in the 100-yard freestyle.
Bob "Mad Dog" Schwenkler
took second to Beveridge in the
100 free while a fine
performance was also turned in
by Brad Procton with a second in
the 200-yard individual medley
and 200-yard butterfly added to
his victory in the 500-yard
freestyle.
Freshman star Mike Bay,
/'

/

possibly Hopkins' best all-around
swimmer this year, set another
pool record in the 200-yard
backstroke clocking a 2:00.5!
Junior Tim Cullinan took a
second in the 500-yard freestyle
and won the 200-yard
breaststroke (2:30.4), while his
classmate Dave Scotti finished
second in both the one and three
meter diving competition.

and tomorrow at noon with

Such a performance would
certainly be very difficult to
repeat and certainly impossible
to top especially since the next
week's contest matched number
one ranked, unbeaten Hopkins
against number two rated,
undefeated Cornell at Cornell.
Half-time saw the Blue Jays on
top 7-4 but it was the third
quarter which proved to be
decisive. Outscoring the hosts
7-1, the Jays rode the practically
flawless goaltending of Kevin
Mahon to a 16-9 thrashing of the
Big Red.
Downhill
From that point on its was all
downhill. Except for a brief
revival in the third period against
Navy, Coach Ciccarone's charges
completed their season in a dull,
listless fashion taking to heart all
of the praise that had been
heaped upon them following the
Cornell win.
Local scribes raised the 1975
edition of the Homewood stick
squad to the level of being one of
thc all-time greats, possibly the
greatest. It was more than sheer
happenstance that the demise of
the Blue Jay stick fortunes
coincided with this flood of
praise showered upon them.
Identical 13-10 wins over
mediocre Brown and Army teams"
set up the Homecoming game
with Navy.
After the two teams battled to
a 7-7 halftime tie, the slumbering
giant awoke and Hopkins
reproduced the Cornell third
quarter; outscoring the
Midshipmen 7-1 and hanging on
for a 16-11 win that looks
misleadingly decisive.
10-0 and looking to finish the
season unblemished, the Jays set
off for College Park to do battle
with what was supposed to be a
rather lackluster bunch of
Terrapins.
Lose
Evidently Coach Buddy
Beardmore's troops had not been
reading the Jays' clipping. Not
only did they refuse to roll over
and play dead but they played an
unbelievably perfect first quarter
of lacrosse during which Hopkins
seemed content to sit back with
the rest of the fans in Byrd
Stadium and marvel at the
spectacle taking place. Before the
Jays knew what hit them,
Maryland led 11-2, building a
lead which proved to be
insurmountable.
Even though the Blue Jays
played the hosts even the rest of
the way, the Terps coasted to a
19-11 win, one of the highest
point totals ever racked up
against a Hopkins ten.
Still rated number one going
into the playoffs, the defending
champs from Homewood played
lethargically against an inspired
group of Generals from
Washington & Lee.
Anxious for revenge after the
Blue Jays had eliminated them in
the 1974 semi-finals, W&L took
the game right to the Jays
defeating them 1 1-7 at
Homewood and this bringing the
Jays' season to an abrupt halt.
With basically the same cast
returning this year the Jays open
up March 20, seeking finer
fortune.

An N-1, Serial: Part I

Alice in Homewoodland: on the path

By DAVE MENDELSOHN
"Oh, my!" Alice thought. "I'll never fit
through/hat door. It's far too small for me.
But perhaps if I squeeze..." Alice poked her
head under the transom, squirmed into the
opening. To her great surprise, she was able
to fit her entire body through, finding this
less difficult than she had anticipated.
Her first impression of Homewoodland
was that it wasn't very different from
whence she had come. Still, the air was
heavier. She was not quite sure yet what the
air was heavier with, but she revelled in the
prospect of finding out. Now, where was
that silly rabbit? He must have gone through
that door if he...
"Oh! Mr. Rabbit! Wait! WAIT!"
The white rabbit closely regarded his
LED digital calendar wristwatch and
muttered, "0„ my Goodness! Goodness
me!" He scampered away, calculus book
under one arm and NHS candle under the
other.
"Wait! Mr. Rabbit! Oh, please wait up!"
Alice tore after the curious hare. She finally
intercepted him, only by outrunning him
and standing in his path.
"Oh, my fur and whiskers! I'm late! I'm
late!" He looked up at Alice from his LED
digital calendar wristwatch and repeated,
"I'm late, damnit! Can't stop now! I'm on
my way to being something!"
"But I just wanted to..."
"Oh yes yes. I'd like to help. Maybe next
Thursday. Good day." He ran off, his
calculator case flopping at his waist.
"But I haven't even told you...," the hare
was gone. "My, he certainly seems busy. He
must be doing something very important,"
she said to no-one in particular. She could
think of nothing to do but seek someone
else's advice. The paths were well enough
marked. This was fortunate, for she found
that it would be very difficult to travel
anywhere that wasn't on a path—the
underbrush was very thick. The signs
marked the junctions. "Chemistry," one
declared in neat letters. Another said,
"Writing Seminars" in fancy script. A
well-beaten trail was marked "Natural
Science." She considered this one for -a
while, but found a gnaller marker under it
which warned, "White Rabbits Only—If
you're anything but a white rabbit, be
assured that you sure as shit aren't likely to
reach your destination, unless, of course,
you happen to want to be a Natural Science
animal." "That's curious," Alice thought.
"What else would be the destination?" Alice
knew that there was much to be learned
about white rabbits.
Meanwhile she was still stuck with the
decision as to which path should be tried.
"Well, I've always liked science. I'll see what
'Physics' is like." She started down the
physics trail.

She had been fighting her way across the
terrain for hours before she finally sat to
rest. "Gee, I sure hope there are connections
between these trails." She did have a lot to
learn about Homewoodland.
After properly admiring the view, she
continued her trek. After another hour she
rounded a pass and stopped abruptly at the
strange sound of...coffee perking? She
stepped from the brush to find a bizarre
Hatter at a nmouth table with many
calculators and a number of coffee urns.
The Hatter studied one calculator intensely.
"Oh,!" he looked up. "Why, hello, there.
You've come to study with me?"
"Well. I guess so. I mean, I just..."
"Wonderful! You'll find this very
interesting. It won't all be, but well come
here and see." The Hatter pointed to a
book. The open page was covered with
diagrams and calculations. "If you figure
this out, you'll understand why a stick looks
bent when half is water."
"My, that should be interesting," Alice
said sincerely. She sat and poured through
the pictures and equations. After a few
minutes she was ready to ask some
questions, but she was cut short by the loud
whistle from a coffee pot.
"Oh!" the Hatter gleamed and patted his
palms together. "It's time to study
something else now."

"I don't understand. I thought I was
going to..."
"What would you like to study, dear?"
"Well, I'm interested in writing. And in
philosophy. I'm also..."
"My dear girl. I'm interested in English
and philosophy too! But we can't spend all
our time learning that, now can we'?"
"Well, I should think not, but..."
"Then you should be pleased to study
more physics. Don't you know that
Homewoodland is one of the finest places in
the world to learn physics?"
"Well, I guess I know." She thought for a
moment. Then, at the risk of being impolite,
she asked, "Pardon me, sir, but is there any
way to get to any of the other trails'?"
"The other trails? My Goodness! How old
are you, little girl?"
"I'm a Junior," Alice replied.
"A Junior in the spring and still doubting
her path! Homewoodland is not the best
place for you, now is it?"
"Well, perhaps not, then, but...well, can I
get to the other trails?"
"It's possible. The connections won't be
blazed for you, but you can find your way
around here if you try."
Another whistle blew. The Hatter poured
himself a cup of coffee and sat at the next
place. Alice was sitting in contemplation
when a two-horned quark jumped from a
coffeepot and shook the brown liquid from
its fur. The Hatter grabbed it stealthily and
stuffed it into another urn. "Go back to
sleep," he scolded impatiently. "I'm not
ready for you yet." "Silly riddler," he
muttered to himself as he turned back to his
studies.
Alice was befuddled. "I think I should
seek the other trails just the same," she said.
"Very well, then," the Hatter replied, not
'taking his eyes from his text. "Best of luck.
I shan't think you'll be able to leave here on
time.
"Should I be anxious to leave'?" Alice
asked innocently.
"Why, of..why...," the Hatter stammered.
He thought deeply for a moment, found
that he could do no studying while engaged
in such evaluation.
Alice, in the meantime, took off directly
into the thick of the woods. She found it
difficult going, but not so hard as she would
have thought. The underbrush was less
dense here, and the trees were more widely
spaced. "But I have no way of knowing
where . I'm headed," she cautioned herself.
The walk was pleasant, though, and while it
was tougher travel than the trail, it was less
steep.
And the change felt awfully good.

.I.)

Alice. thought this might be a good idea.
The Hatter gestured for her to move to
the next text at the seat beside her. Alice sat
at the new book, but found that it was more
physics. "Pardon me," she started, "but
shouldn't this be a new subject?"
"Why of course! What have you got
there?"
"Uhm. It's about heat. Calories."
"Of course!, Of course! A marvelous
topic!"
"But..."

, Convocation aftermath

Can Johns Hopkins University live with Princess Ashraf?

Baltimore Police outside Lyric
•

By ERIC GARLAND
The awarding of an honorary degree to
Princess Ashraf Pahlavi of Iran at last
Sunday's convocation ceremonies has
aroused considerable controversy about
the University's intentions and integrity.
Hopkins has seemingly ignored the
Princess' background, the political
activities of the Shah,(her twin brother),
and protests from the community.
The University's official connection
With Iran is an academic exchange
Program between theSchool of Health
Services and the College of Health
Sciences at the Reza Pahlavi Medical
Center in Tehran. The Iranian Students
Association (ISA) holds that the Shah has
donated money to the Med School, and
that the degree was granted in response to
(and in hopes of future) grants. Dr. Harry
Woolf, Provost of the University, has said,
"We don't get any money from the
Iranian government, only the fees
covering faculty expenses at the College."
The jump from the exchange program
relationship to the degree award to
Ashraf reveals a very murky process.
Woolf heads the Honorary Degree
Committee, which is composed of seven
members from all divisions of the
University. Dr. Richard Macksey stressed
that the Committee is more concerned
With the Commencement awards in May,
While the President customarily
nominates . the Commemoration
speaker(s). The Committee last met
October 28 to review a memo sent by
Woolf listing the candidates for February
and May. "We're not concerned on a
discussion basis with Commemoration
Day," said Macksey, "if the Committee
exists, the Committee ratifies." The three
recipients of Commemoration degrees
were proposed by President Muller; they
were perfunctorily . approved by the
committee, with no questions asked or
Protests received. No vitae, however, was
supplied about the candidates."We know
there's controversy," said Woolf, "but
don't know the facts of the charges. It
looked pretty clean to me at the time."
Mike Hoffheimer, a Hopkins junior and
one of five persons arrested Sunday,
replied that "if he feels that way, it's
embarassing for an institution to not
know what's going on in the world. How
could it look clean, with people from
Hopkins over there, seeing what's going
on."
Woolf termed Ashraf s nomination
symbolic", citing her role in helping and
guiding the development of the College of
Health Sciences. In the terms of an ISA
member, the Princess, "after the Shah, is
the most hated person by all people in

Iran." Ashraf s reputation is notorious, to
say. the least. "Of all women in the
world," stated ne faculty member,"why
was she singled out, a woman with that
kind of reputation, from that kind of
government?"
The Washington Post, February 23,
1976, reported that "one of the Shah's
closest relatives who continues to be
surrounded by widespread suspicion is his
twin sister, Princess Ashraf, a world
leader in woman's rights movements. The
Princess, whose three marriages and
jet-set living style have offended many
Iranians, is said to be deeply involved in a
number of 'shady deals'. 'Take the
trucking industry: said a wealthy Tehran
businessman, 'not a truck can move
anywhere without a payoff going to
Ashraf.' In the days before Iran was
swimming in oil wealth, it was widely
believed that Princess Ashraf profited
from illegal opium deals involving Iran's
large poppy production."
This latter charge is documented by
Michael Parrish, an Indiana University
faculty member, in the December 1962
issue of The Minority of One."Two years
ago," he writes, "the Swiss police arrested
the Shah's sister, Princess Ashraf, for
having several suitcases full of heroin."
She was on her way to the U.S. at the
time. Hoffheimer added that "she has
been arrested for drug-running at least
three times in European airports," and
that her diplomatic immunity had been
used to successfully carry out the
operations. Her personal trafficking may
have been discontinued with the wealth
brought by Iranian oil (thus freeing her to
be a "humanitarian"), but Iran remains
the country with the most addicts per
population (an estimated half million by
the New York Times), and the Shah in
1969 removed a ban which prohibited the
cultivation of opium.
The political corruption of the royal
family was described by Nation, April 12,
1965. It seems that the donation of
millions of U.S. foreign aid dollars to Iran
was quickly followed by the deposit of
millions in a numbered Swiss bank
account to the "Pahlavi Foundation".
Photostat copies of the account revealed
a $3 million check withdrawn to Ashraf,
an amount exceeded only by $15 million
given to the Shah's wife. Eleven years
later the Post is still reporting on the
"suspected" corruption of the Shah and
his relatives.
The Post, though, falters in describing
Ashraf "a world leader in woman's rights

movements." "Perhaps she is representing
the rights of the woman of her type or
class," said the ISA member. "The
women of Iran, the workers and patriots,
are worse off than ever. The workers
make fifty cents a day; women prisoners
are tortured and raped in front of their
husbands and brothers."
The political repression of the Shah's
regime is unquestioned. Martin Ennals,
Secretary of Amnesty International, has
stated that "no country in the world has
a worse record in human rights than
Iran." There are an estimated 100,000
political prisoners (4000 women), the
majority of whom are tortured; at least
four hundred have been executed in the
past four years. Secret military tribunals
decide the fate of prisoners, with
torture-induced confessions common.
Repeated attempts by international
organizations to send observ,l
have been
met with forced deportations.
"No one can claim to be naive about
that (the political repression)," said the
professor. Woolf, though, declared that
"it's not our role to judge" and said the
controversy was dismissed at the time of
selection. "We try to have candidates
with a bearing on the University, some
kind of proper affiliation," he explained.
"The Princess was awarded as a patron of
the University program in Iran." Again,
the faculty member questioned, "why
her, why not a doctor, or someone in the

The Princess Ashraf

health program?" Ashrafs position with
the College of Health Sciences, as the
"political and monetary backbone"(from
a Hopkins doctor involved in the
program), is not the result of any special
merit; she was appointed by the Shah.,
"When Hopkins does something like
that," the ISA member said, "it
legitimates Iran and its reactionary
regime."
The process of the degree award was
not handled like a ceremonious event.
The Honorary Degree Committee,
naturally, knew of the nomination, but
both Macksey and Dr. Owen Phillips had
trouble recalling the minimal approval
procedure, and 'Macksey only
remembered Ashraf when reading over
the convocation procedure Sunday
morning. Outside of the marshals, no
faculty members were told of the
conferral; "nobody had the chance to
protest," said the professor. When one of
the persons invited to be a marshal
withdrew upon seeing the selection of the
Princess, the University quietly ignored
his action. Most people first found out
about Ashraf's award at the
Commemoration Sunday.
One group that knew well in advance,
however, was SAVAK, Iranian secret
police. In cooperation with Hopkins
security, federal agents (one in a Hopkins
security uniform), and the Baltimore City
Police, agents in plain clothes were at the
Lyric Theater under the cover of
"newspaper reporters". When the
demonstration inside the theater began,
the SAVAK agents physically carried
people out of the auditorium,
undertaking all the police duties up to the
actual arrest. SAVAK had meetings and
radio contact with the police; in short,
they were condoned by the University.
Bodyguards for foreign visitors is normal
procedure, but in this case, the emphasis
was on hiding any connection with the
Iranian government.
As for the arrest, Hoffheimer and the
four others had to wait six hours in jail
before they were told of the charges
against them (disorderly conduct). While
they were in the basement of the Lyric,
the police were heard negotiating who
was to be the arresting officer.
Hoffheimer asked who the officer was;
the reply, "I'll tell you later." During the
booking, the police were on radio talking
to Hopkins security about the charges.
Apparently, the six hour delay was due to
the time taken by the administration to
decide on the charges. Another gloss on
the arrest is the fact that Hopkins
security guards were brought into the jail
to identify the protesters for sure
identification at the trial later.
With the award of the degree to Ashraf
and the arrest of the demonstrators past
history, the University now has to justify
its actions. The protesters did upset the
ceremony, with Woolf remarking that
"it's not a road to justice," and that it
was "a disruption of Hopkins' private
celebration." Hoffheimer counters, of
course, that "Ashraf is breaking into
Iranian lives every day. An honorary
degree is not a private thing; Ashraf is not
just an ordinary person." The
presentation of the doctorate, with the
"short-circuit" of the Degree Committee,
the secrecy surrounding information
about the award, and the Princess' and
Iran's backgrounds, calls for something
beyond the citation words of last Sunday.

Towson State radio goes FM
By J.D. CONSIDINE
About a year ago, I happened
to be in the Towson State
College Student Center, and in
the course of my wanderings, I
noticed music pervading the
general hotel-lobby atmosphere
of the building. Muzak, I figured
(although it was far more hip
than the general WLIF fare);
until a voice was discerned
mumbling some explanation of
what was played.
This was WVTS, Towson's
carrier current station. Like most
carrier current stations, it had a
limited following, intermittant
broadcast hours, and very little
potential. Unbeknownst to the
general public, though, help was
on the way: FM.
Right now, Towson is in its
third week of FM programming,
with WCVT-FM a broadcast
reality at 89. What may seem to
be an overnight transition,
however, was anything but
sudden; the metamorphosis of
Carrier Current to FM took over
three years.
What does it take to go FM?
"A lot of work," to quote station
manager Steve Curran. Outside of
the basic procedure of obtaining
permission, a frequency, and a
license there are the problems
involved in equipment.
First of all, money. The cost
for Towson's FM station has
been almost entirely for
equipment, and has totalled
approximately $36,000. With the
exception of the tower
construction ( due to county
laws), all equipment installation
has been done by _student
volunteers.
But there were also problems
with personnel, and fulfilling the
F.C.C. guidelines for an
Educational FM station.
For starters, the station is
almost entirely student staffed
and managed. This creates a
strong core of support for the
station, but it also has
drawbacks. When exams and
vacations occur, it will not be
easy to get all the DJ's to their
shows, let alone on time.
"Mid-terms are coming up," says
Curran, "and this should be an
indication of how things will go."
Although he expects to weather
the exams, the end of the term
poses yet another problem. Even
with 90% of the staff living in the
area as full-time residents, Curran
expects scheduling problems.
As an educational station, they
are obligated to serve the
community, which right now is
not easy. "Since we went on in
Mid-term, we really couldn't start
any educational courses-by-radio,
"Curran stated.
For now, they have two
student created and produced
educational programs, Media
Makers and Business Beat,
broadcast from 9:00-9:30
weekdays. The rest of the
programming is based on
Classical music from 6:00-9:00
a.m., and Jazz from 8:00 to
midnight. The rest of the
broadcast day is 'progressive
radio'."
Doesn't all that progressive
sound like typical carrier-current
radio? "Yeah, and I'm not too

pleased, but at the moment,
there's not a whole lot I can do,"
said Curran. "We're a new
station, and we've still got a lot
of growing to do."
When asked about the chances
for an FM station at Hopkins,
Curran gave this evaluation:
"I really can't see Hopkins
with an FM station for at least
five years. There's a lot of
preliminary action that has to be
taken, and one thing that is
essential is an experienced
Advisor, with radio background
and an F.C.C. first class license.

It just makes everything so much
easier; he would know how to fill
out the forms, how to deal with
the government officials.
"As for a Mass Comm
program, you don't need to be a
Mass Comm major to be in radio.
You could just as easily be an Art
Student.
"It's fastest if you can get all
volunteers. Of course it will take
time; you've got to expect it to
change hands. But we had full
support of our Student
Government, and it's taken a
long time, but we're here."

The return of the
Thin White Duke
Station to Station, David
Bowie's latest lp, is already
beginning to generate a
snowballing excitement with
multiple hits flying out of radios
into the waiting ears of his
beloved young Americans. The
"Thin White Duke" is staging
more than a return; the boy with
the animal grace has carefully
mapped out a Bowie year; after
the whirlwind coast-to-coast
tour, a movie will be released for
all of us to gawk and coo at, and
from there Bowie's momentum
and ability to mesmerize his
audience could carry him
anywhere—perhaps to his own
recently disclosed fancy of ruling
the world.
Though Bowie has more fans
than ever, long-standing
aficionados of the man can only
feel some disappointment at the
general musical mediocrity of
Station to Station. It is a
reflection of Bowie's lastest
remarks in Rolling Stone
magazine where he denounced
rock 'n roll. as "musical soma,"
very close to "becoming an
immobile, sterile fascist that
constantly spews its propaganda
on every arm of the media." But
the writing on the new album
remains intensely personal, joyful
and optimistic, having its roots in
Thinky Dory and earlier works.
The new devotees applaud the
absense of glitter and feminine

garb, but it should be
remembered that the
androgynous darling has always
remained a few steps ahead of
the pack and now points to a
mellowing in these golden years.
There can be no doubt that
David Bowie is about to make his
bid for messiah, a role he's
groomed himself for these last
seven years. What is scary is that
Bowie's remarks on the potential
dangers of popular music seem to
be exactly what he is
trying—except that I think he has
some important things to say.
always has. He is about to launch
a cinema career and start his own
production • company. To be sure.
the future theatrics of David
Bowie will be more interesting
than national political struggles
to the average American. Let's
hope -somebody , maybe even
Bowie himself, has enough
common sense to keep things uI
perspective.
But remember, we are dealing
with the one and only ZiggY
Stardust. Bowie has put down his
past roles, but Ziggy was an
amazing piece of autobiography,
and has so far proven to be the
true David Bowie story.'
We are about to witness not
only Bowie's rock 'n roll suicide,
but most likely ours as well.
David Bowie will be appearing
at the Capitol Center on March
13 and 14.

Hopkins cannot expect to

women led
her to mobilize the educated and

The organization which resulted
from this activity has evolved
into a model center for service to
women. Pricess Ashraf holds as a
basic truth the proposition that
only when women achieve their
full potential in human society
will men achieve theirs.
When Her Imperial Highness
was appointed to the United
Nations as chief of the Iranian
delegation, she exploited this
international forum to continue
her dedication to humanitarian
cuases. In 1968, she became the
first woman to preside over a
major international
proceeding—the International
Conference on Human Rights. In
1975, she was instrumental in the
organization of the International
Women's Year Program and was a
major author of the World Plan
of Action approved in Mexico
City by delegates from 130
nations calling for the
achievement of full and equal
rights for women throughout the
world in the course of the next

decade.
The Johns Hopkins University
has a special interest in the honor
we bestow today upon Princess
Ashraf. Medical care, particularly
for those outside major
population centers, is one of her
country's most critical problems.
Over the years, many Iranian
physicians have received their
training at Johns Hopkins, and
because of that earlier experience
an academic exchange program
has been established between this
University and the College of
Health Sciences at the Reza
Pahlavi Medical Center in Tehran.
The goal is to develop a broad
spectrum of health professionals
to meet the specific needs of
Iran, where over half the
population still resides in small
villages.

This program has by no means
been an unidirectional learning
experience. Physicians in this
country, too, are clustered
around population centers, and
the solutions found in Iran to the
problem of maldistiibution
medical care may have a
significant impact upon the
delivery of medical care in the
United States. The success of this
entire effort is no small measure
of a reflection of the foresight of
Princess Ashraf, who earlY
recognized the needs of her
people and helped bring together
her country's resources to meet
those needs.
Mr. President, it is a distinct
pleasure to present for the degree
of Doctor of Laws, Her Imperial
Highness, Princess Ashraf Pahlavi
of Iran.

Delta Phi tops brands X, IT and Z easily
By MIKE DEAK
Fraternity Party!
The phrase alone harkens
visions of old movies and foolish
dreams, of more prosaic times
when the threat of communism
was not yet upon the land. Ali
yes, I can see it now. The
Whiffenpoof Club harmonizing
"The Sweetheart of Sigma Chi"
while crooning young men
rowing on the lake strum their
ukeleles and serenade their
amantes. Meanwhile, back at
the fraternity house, couples
have strewn themselves about the
veranda engaging in some heavy
necking, never daring-- God
forbid!--to go all the way. And if,
at the end of the evening while a
Connie Francis record coos softly
in the background, some
romantic fraternity brother pins
his girl, she has all the right in the
world to consider herself a
"lucky lady".
Needless to say, this just is not
the case anymore. Like all other
great American institutions,
fraternities have taken a severe
beating in the last decade.
Radical ideas undermined the
basic bourgeois concept of
fraternities, changing them into
nothing more than formalized
social clubs. In the late sixties,
hippies rightly charged
fraternities as being not relevant
enough, paragons of what was
wrong in America. So, like
fugitive radicals, fraternities went
underground waiting for more
politically petceful times to
make a rousing comeback. Now,
with the apathetic seventies upon
us like a shroud, frats have risen
from the grave and once again
gained a status that has to be
reckoned with.
I don't know what made me
attend the numberous fraternity
parties this month. Perhaps it was
the anthropology major showing

through, the relentless
ethnographer gathering data for
that ultimate monograph on
American puberty rites. Or, more
likely, the current sultry
February weather brings out a
reckless streak of hedonism in
me, just as heat applied to a boil
will bring the pus to the surface.
Whatever ther eason, I put on my
most elegant finery and bravely
ventured onto the dark Baltimore
streets in search of cheap thrills
and fraternity parties.
I should have gone no further
than my first stop, St. Elmo's
Hall, the grand residence of Delta
Phi. In past years, Delta Phi had
achieved a nefarious and false
reputation of being nothing more
than a den of stuffed shirts and
spoiled preppies. But the only
truth in these allegations is in the
fraternity's boast of having "the
highest class drunks around." In
reality, Delta Phi members are no
different than the rest of us
except they are a tad more
affluent and conservative. These
last two traits should not be
frowned upon because they
enable the fraternity to give the
best parties at Hopkins.

With their virtually unlimited
resources, Delta Phi was able to
snare Rodeo Rick for its parties.
Most importantly, for hard
drinkers like myself, Delta Phi
had the sense and class to have
imported Dortmunder Union
beer and to serve it in authentic
glasses. The dark draught flowed
easily over the palate and gave
the tastebuds a thrill they will
not soon forget. With cries of
"Beer here" in the finest Yankee
Stadium tradition emanating
from behind the bar, I forgot I
was at a fraternity party and
started enjoying myself.
Using the flimsy excuse that I
had to pay my respects to other
friends, I had to take leave of
Delta Phi and stumble to the
next fraternity. Unfortunately,
fraternity X (I use the
anonymous letter due to the
stringent laws of libel) proved to
be a foreshadowing of the
mediocore parties to follow.
Walking into X (after talking to
an Arab friend outside; X attracts
all kinds) was like entering a
funeral parlor whose air
conditioning had broken down.
The narrow entrance hall was

lined with lacrosse sticks am
bodies. You could tell th.
difference; the sticks were no
drinking beer.
Making my way through thi:
serious parody of a somnabulis
convention, I was reminded o
Orpheus' descent into Hades. TM
rooms were so dimly lit I coulc

Arixtyn,..d self-righteous schmuck..know what I mean?'
BUY, from page 3
can't sing. Time before that, it
was one of the Berrigans—and he
wound up in jail! Now the
columns favorable to Carter.
Jimmy's gonna need an exorcist
to protect him from Wills! I hear
Rabbi Baruch Korff might take
the job. N-L: What was your
reaction when you heard of
Carter's New Hampshire victory?
Burns: It wasn't a victory! We've
Just been through that. But, to be
on the safe side, I called my
broker and had him buy up all
the peanut butter futures he
could smear on the Commodities
market. Then, I called Marvin
Mandel in Annapolis and urged
him to enter the race for the

Presidency. "Marve," I said, "As
long as Hotsy's rasing so much
gelt for you, you might as well
have some fun and spend it on
yourself. Forget the damn
shysters! You can pay them
anytime. What are they going to
do? Take you to court? They'd
have to wait in line. Besides, if a
hick like Carter could get so many
votes, just _imagine; what a
street-smart Baltimorean like
yourself could do!" N-L: You
think Mandel would make a good
candidate, let alone a President?
Burns: The best! America is now
ready for a Marvin Mandel in the
White House. We've matured as a
nation; we no longer have the old
Puritan bourgeois censorious
mentality. We don't want Our

leaders to be saints—as long as
they can carry off their sins well,
we support them. Teddy
Kennedy could win. John
Connally still has a chance at
national office. They have
panache. So does Marvin. But
Nixon didn't have it—he acted
like a self-righteous schmuck; he
embarrassed the nation, so we
forced him out. Now Marvin
would make an extraordinarily
appealing candidate. That
corncob pipe of his would be the
newest status symbol. He's
divorced—but so is everybody
else nowadays. His new wife is a
charmer. He can have witty
people like Louie Goldstein and
Hymie Pressman as
speechwriters. Marvin should

start a new political party—the
Land of Pleasant Living Party;
run on a platform of steamed
crabs, beer, race tracks, lottery
tickets, legalized off-track betting
and no-fault divorce. I tell you,
the whole ethos of the state of
Maryland could permeate the rest
of the country. It's just what
America needs. N-L: So you
think Marvin Mandel would be
the most appealing Presidential
candidate? Who would he getfor
a finning-mate? Otto Kerner? or
Tony Boyle to get the labor
vote? Burns: I was hoping for
Frank Sinatra, but Kerner does
have a lot of class-limited name
recognition nowadays, though.
N-L: Wouldn't the indictment
hurt Marvin?

It takes the best
to challen e
all the rest.

Burns: Not at all. Only a
conviction would ruin him—but
that won't happen for a long
time. You see, the Law is so
slow, Marvin's term as governor
will expire before the jury is even
selected. By the way, I'm
predicting the trial will
eventually be held in Sitka,
Alaska, in 1984. You need a
change of venue. No jury in
Maryland will ever convict
Marvin of anything. The
prosecutor will insist on moving
the trial. N-L: What will the
chatge be? Performing an illegal
nose operation on an Eskimo
with the collaboration of Neil
Solomon, M.D.? Burns: I'll do
the funny stuff around here. Say,
I thought your top staff writer,
Robert Fulton Buchanan, would
be doing this interview. What
happened to him? N-L: Sorry,
Bob's tied up. Wally Orlinsky
sent him out to get the prune
danish for Mayor Schaefer's
lunch. Burns: Well, you make a
lousy straight man. N-L: What
about Birch Bayh? Burns: Birch
Bay? Isn't that off the coast of
New Brunswick? Yeah, I saw
Curt Gowdy and Carl
Yastrzemski fishing for cod on
the "American Sportsman" up
there. N-L: Be serious. What are
his chances? Burns: I don't
know. Would you buy a used
birch from that man? I wouldn't.
N-L: And Fred Harris? Burns:
Never had a prayer. The only
people who still think Harris is
electable are out to lunch,
visiting the planet Pluto. You
know what I mean? N-L: Are
you referring to the editor's
recent article endorsing Harris?
Burns: Tu tienes razon, chico.
Now give me my bus ticket to
Florida.

STUDY IN THE HIMALAYAS THIS SUMMER
A seven-week expedition is planned for this summer to study the human ecology of the Himalayas.
There is a planned program of study including the area of health and nutrition. Trekking from an
elevation of 1,500 feet down in the jungles of Nepal, up through the heart of the Himalayas to an
elevation of 15,000 feet, high on the arid Tibetan Plateau behind the major mountain massifs of
Dhaulagiri and Annapurna, the class will study the way different people live and why. The
comprehensive fee that covers all expenses if $1,935 from May 25th to July 11th. Three semester
hours of credit possible through the Department of Geography and Enviromental Engineering at
Johns Hopkins. Credits require approval by the Department and by the Dean of Undergraduate
Studies after completion of the program of study and submission of a satisfactory paper. For
information, contact: The Woodlands Institute, Spruce Knob Mountain, Cherry Grove, West Virginia
26803 or M.G. Wolman, Ames 513, JHU.

1976 Hopkins lacrosse: looking for finer fortunes
By STEPHEN LEVIN
WE HAVE A COUPLE OF
SCORES TO SETTLE!
That's the call to arms as the
1976 Hopkins lacrosse team
convenes for its opening week of
Practice. With memories of a
bitterly disappointing ending to
what had opened as an extremely
Promising season fresh .in their
minds, Coach Henry Ciccarone,
his staff and players are out to
avenge the two late season losses
which destroyed all hopes for an
undefeated year and with that
the chance for an unprecedented

second straight NCAA title.
The Blue Jays finished a highly
respectable third in the final
season poll especially considering
the season had been termed a
"rebuilding" one at the outset
due to the loss of eleven seniors
from 1974's national
championship squad.
In recapping the 1975 season,
one has to start with the
elevation of Henry Ciccarone
from the position of associate
coach to the head coaching spot
when Robert Scott left ro
dedicate all of his time to his

duties as Athletic
Director. Chic got a rude
introduction to his head coaching
duties when Hopkins opened its'
title defense by edging a spirited
bunch of Wahoos from Virginia
10-9 in overtime on Homewood
Field.
Impressive victories followed
over weaker opponents Denison,
Yale, Washington College and
Princeton. Against the Tigers,
Hopkins unleashed its most
furious offensive barrage of the
season, papering the Princeton
net with 22 goals!

All this resulted in a number
one ranking for the Homewood
stickmen and set-up the first of
two consecutive clashes which
would truly test the Jays'
strength. First was the clash between
the collegiate champs and the
club champs; Hopkins vs. the
Long Island Lacrosse Club, a
Saturday night game at
Homewood. What was previewed
as a titanic struggle between the
best of two worlds turned into a
rout with the uppity youngsters
dominating, 20-9.

F&M eliminates Jays from playoffs
By BRUCE FOX
Hopkins' Comforteers will
play host to the Middle Atlantic
Conference Swimming and
Diving Championships this
weekend, after closing out their
regular season schedule with a
54-50 win over Dickinson College
Tuesday.
The Dickinson meet, held at
Carlisel, Penn., was one of the
easiest of the season for the Blue
Jays, with many of Hopkins'
swimmers either not swimming
or entering events other than
their specialties.

Freshman Roy Beveridge was a
dual winner in the mmet,
combining a Dickinson pool
record-setting performance in the
200-yard freestyle (1:53.9) with
a first in the 100-yard freestyle.
Bob "Mad Dog" Schwenkler
took second to Beveridge in the
100 free while a fine
performance was also turned in
by Brad Procton with a second in
the 200-yard individual medley
and 200-yard butterfly added to
his victory in the 500-yard
freestyle.
Freshman star Mike Bay,
/'

/

possibly Hopkins' best all-around
swimmer this year, set another
pool record in the 200-yard
backstroke clocking a 2:00.5!
Junior Tim Cullinan took a
second in the 500-yard freestyle
and won the 200-yard
breaststroke (2:30.4), while his
classmate Dave Scotti finished
second in both the one and three
meter diving competition.

and tomorrow at noon with
finals and consolations to be held
both days at 8 p.m.

Such a performance would
certainly be very difficult to
repeat and certainly impossible
to top especially since the next
week's contest matched number
one ranked, unbeaten Hopkins
against number two rated,
undefeated Cornell at Cornell.
Half-time saw the Blue Jays on
top 7-4 but it was the third
quarter which proved to be
decisive. Outscoring the hosts
7-1, the Jays rode the practically
flawless goaltending of Kevin
Mahon to a 16-9 thrashing of the
Big Red.
Downhill
From that point on its was all
downhill. Except for a brief
revival in the third period against
Navy, Coach Ciccarone's charges
completed their season in a dull,
listless fashion taking to heart all
of the praise that had been
heaped upon them following the
Cornell win.
Local scribes raised the 1975
edition of the Homewood stick
squad to the level of being one of
thc all-time greats, possibly the
greatest. It was more than sheer
happenstance that the demise of
the Blue Jay stick fortunes
coincided with this flood of
praise showered upon them.
Identical 13-10 wins over
mediocre Brown and Army teams"
set up the Homecoming game
with Navy.
After the two teams battled to
a 7-7 halftime tie, the slumbering
giant awoke and Hopkins
reproduced the Cornell third
quarter; outscoring the
Midshipmen 7-1 and hanging on
for a 16-11 win that looks
misleadingly decisive.
10-0 and looking to finish the
season unblemished, the Jays set
off for College Park to do battle
with what was supposed to be a
rather lackluster bunch of
Terrapins.
Lose
Evidently Coach Buddy
Beardmore's troops had not been
reading the Jays' clipping. Not
only did they refuse to roll over
and play dead but they played an
unbelievably perfect first quarter
of lacrosse during which Hopkins
seemed content to sit back with
the rest of the fans in Byrd
Stadium and marvel at the
spectacle taking place. Before the
Jays knew what hit them,
Maryland led 11-2, building a
lead which proved to be
insurmountable.
Even though the Blue Jays
played the hosts even the rest of
the way, the Terps coasted to a
19-11 win, one of the highest
point totals ever racked up
against a Hopkins ten.
Still rated number one going
into the playoffs, the defending
champs from Homewood played
lethargically against an inspired
group of Generals from
Washington & Lee.
Anxious for revenge after the
Blue Jays had eliminated them in
the 1974 semi-finals, W&L took
the game right to the Jays
defeating them 1 1-7 at
Homewood and this bringing the
Jays' season to an abrupt halt.
With basically the same cast
returning this year the Jays open
up March 20, seeking finer
fortune.

Alice in Homewoodland: on the path

By DAVE MENDELSOHN
"Oh, my!" Alice thought. "I'll never fit
through/hat door. It's far too small for me.
But perhaps if I squeeze..." Alice poked her
head under the transom, squirmed into the
opening. To her great surprise, she was able
to fit her entire body through, finding this
less difficult than she had anticipated.
Her first impression of Homewoodland
was that it wasn't very different from
whence she had come. Still, the air was
heavier. She was not quite sure yet what the
air was heavier with, but she revelled in the
prospect of finding out. Now, where was
that silly rabbit? He must have gone through
that door if he...
"Oh! Mr. Rabbit! Wait! WAIT!"
The white rabbit closely regarded his
LED digital calendar wristwatch and
muttered, "0„ my Goodness! Goodness
me!" He scampered away, calculus book
under one arm and NHS candle under the
other.
"Wait! Mr. Rabbit! Oh, please wait up!"
Alice tore after the curious hare. She finally
intercepted him, only by outrunning him
and standing in his path.
"Oh, my fur and whiskers! I'm late! I'm
late!" He looked up at Alice from his LED
digital calendar wristwatch and repeated,
"I'm late, damnit! Can't stop now! I'm on
my way to being something!"
"But I just wanted to..."
"Oh yes yes. I'd like to help. Maybe next
Thursday. Good day." He ran off, his
calculator case flopping at his waist.
"But I haven't even told you...," the hare
was gone. "My, he certainly seems busy. He
must be doing something very important,"
she said to no-one in particular. She could
think of nothing to do but seek someone
else's advice. The paths were well enough
marked. This was fortunate, for she found
that it would be very difficult to travel
anywhere that wasn't on a path—the
underbrush was very thick. The signs
marked the junctions. "Chemistry," one
declared in neat letters. Another said,
"Writing Seminars" in fancy script. A
well-beaten trail was marked "Natural
Science." She considered this one for -a
while, but found a gnaller marker under it
which warned, "White Rabbits Only—If
you're anything but a white rabbit, be
assured that you sure as shit aren't likely to
reach your destination, unless, of course,
you happen to want to be a Natural Science
animal." "That's curious," Alice thought.
"What else would be the destination?" Alice
knew that there was much to be learned
about white rabbits.
Meanwhile she was still stuck with the
decision as to which path should be tried.
"Well, I've always liked science. I'll see what
'Physics' is like." She started down the
physics trail.

She had been fighting her way across the
terrain for hours before she finally sat to
rest. "Gee, I sure hope there are connections
between these trails." She did have a lot to
learn about Homewoodland.
After properly admiring the view, she
continued her trek. After another hour she
rounded a pass and stopped abruptly at the
strange sound of...coffee perking? She
stepped from the brush to find a bizarre
Hatter at a nmouth table with many
calculators and a number of coffee urns.
The Hatter studied one calculator intensely.
"Oh,!" he looked up. "Why, hello, there.
You've come to study with me?"
"Well. I guess so. I mean, I just..."
"Wonderful! You'll find this very
interesting. It won't all be, but well come
here and see." The Hatter pointed to a
book. The open page was covered with
diagrams and calculations. "If you figure
this out, you'll understand why a stick looks
bent when half is water."
"My, that should be interesting," Alice
said sincerely. She sat and poured through
the pictures and equations. After a few
minutes she was ready to ask some
questions, but she was cut short by the loud
whistle from a coffee pot.
"Oh!" the Hatter gleamed and patted his
palms together. "It's time to study
something else now."

"I don't understand. I thought I was
going to..."
"What would you like to study, dear?"
"Well, I'm interested in writing. And in
philosophy. I'm also..."
"My dear girl. I'm interested in English
and philosophy too! But we can't spend all
our time learning that, now can we'?"
"Well, I should think not, but..."
"Then you should be pleased to study
more physics. Don't you know that
Homewoodland is one of the finest places in
the world to learn physics?"
"Well, I guess I know." She thought for a
moment. Then, at the risk of being impolite,
she asked, "Pardon me, sir, but is there any
way to get to any of the other trails'?"
"The other trails? My Goodness! How old
are you, little girl?"
"I'm a Junior," Alice replied.
"A Junior in the spring and still doubting
her path! Homewoodland is not the best
place for you, now is it?"
"Well, perhaps not, then, but...well, can I
get to the other trails?"
"It's possible. The connections won't be
blazed for you, but you can find your way
around here if you try."
Another whistle blew. The Hatter poured
himself a cup of coffee and sat at the next
place. Alice was sitting in contemplation
when a two-horned quark jumped from a
coffeepot and shook the brown liquid from
its fur. The Hatter grabbed it stealthily and
stuffed it into another urn. "Go back to
sleep," he scolded impatiently. "I'm not
ready for you yet." "Silly riddler," he
muttered to himself as he turned back to his
studies.
Alice was befuddled. "I think I should
seek the other trails just the same," she said.
"Very well, then," the Hatter replied, not
'taking his eyes from his text. "Best of luck.
I shan't think you'll be able to leave here on
time.
"Should I be anxious to leave'?" Alice
asked innocently.
"Why, of..why...," the Hatter stammered.
He thought deeply for a moment, found
that he could do no studying while engaged
in such evaluation.
Alice, in the meantime, took off directly
into the thick of the woods. She found it
difficult going, but not so hard as she would
have thought. The underbrush was less
dense here, and the trees were more widely
spaced. "But I have no way of knowing
where . I'm headed," she cautioned herself.
The walk was pleasant, though, and while it
was tougher travel than the trail, it was less
steep.
And the change felt awfully good.

The Hatter gestured for her to move to
the next text at the seat beside her. Alice sat
at the new book, but found that it was more
physics. "Pardon me," she started, "but
shouldn't this be a new subject?"
"Why of course! What have you got
there?"
"Uhm. It's about heat. Calories."
"Of course!, Of course! A marvelous
topic!"
"But..."
